arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred per s.28, s.44 and Abraham precedent

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer had power under s. 28 of the Income-tax Act to impose penalty in the course of assessment of a firm even if the firm stood at the date of the order dissolved by the death of one of its partners.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in a recent judgment-C. A. Abraham Income-tax Officer, Kottayam  1 -held that the Income-tax Officer had power under s. 28 of the Income-tax Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44 sets up machinery for assessing discontinued firms, applying Chapter IV provisions including s.28; partners jointly and severally liable.

holdings.text: s.44 makes provisions of Chapter IV applicable to all discontinued firms including registered firms.

anchor.surface_text: But s. 44 makes the provisions of Chapter IV, so far as may be, applicable to assessment when any business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm has been discontinued the section declares liability of all discontinued firms and number merely of unregistered firms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nothing in s.44 limits to unregistered firms; approves Andhra Pradesh HC decision in Mareddy Krishna Reddy on registered firm.

holdings.text: A firm is a 'person' under s.28 liable to penalty; penalty liability not conditioned on tax payable by the firm.

anchor.surface_text: The expression person is defined in s. 2 a  of the Act as including a Hindu undivided family and a local authority. That evidently is number an exhaustive definition and recourse is permissible to the General Clauses Act which says in s. 3 42  that a person includes any companypany or association or body of individuals

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Person' includes body of individuals per s.2(a), General Clauses s.3(42), proviso(d); cl.(b) shows no precondition of tax liability; cites Khushiram precedent; s.23(5) merely collection method.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was satisfied in the course of assessment proceedings for 1949-50 that the firm concealed income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment order is dated November 10, 1951, and there is an endorsement at the foot of the assessment order by the Income-tax Officer that action

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsement on assessment order dated Nov 10, 1951 states action under s.28 taken for concealment, indicating satisfaction during proceedings.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that no penalty under s.28(1)(c) could be imposed on the firm after dissolution; penalty orders valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was in error in holding that penalty companyld number be imposed under s. 28  1   c  upon the firm Messrs. S. V. Veerappan

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court view based on s.28, s.44, Abraham precedent, definitions, and satisfaction evidence.
